Award.AwardTitle: BCC-SBE: PI-NET: Poli-Informatics Research Coordination Network

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Research Collaborative Network (RCN) advances the new interdisciplinary field of PoliInformatics. PoliInformatics brings informatics to political research by promoting the analysis of very large and unstructured government datasets. The central objective of the RCN is to encourage scholars representing diverse disciplines such as computer science, information science, electrical engineering, statistics and computational linguistics to collaborate and apply their skills to the analysis of U.S. government activity. Over a three year period, the RCN will establish a new interdisciplinary scholarly network; conduct research competitions and workshops; train the next generation of PoliInformatics researchers; and produce a compendium of papers demonstrating the importance of this new field.

Large government data sets inspire previously unimagined research questions, analytic methods, and technology tools. The RCN will lead to valuable innovations in how government activities such as lawmaking, budgeting and policy implementation are studied and understood. It will encourage highly capable scholars possessing diverse research perspectives to focus their attention on important technical and substantive challenges presented by rapidly expanding repositories of government data. The infrastructure that these researchers develop to address these challenges will then be available for use by others--students, journalists, interest groups, and citizens. Thus a critically important broader impact of the RCN will be to foster improved public understanding of the roles and activities of the U.S. government.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this Research Coordination Network (RCN) was to encourage social scientists and computer scientists to take advantage of the growing number of digitized repositories of government data, including text. In 2009, the federal government required all agencies to share extensive information on the internet. This created lots of research opportunities, but the sheer volume called for new methods of analysis. We were particularly interested in promoting collaborations where political scientists would apply their domain knowledge and computer scientists would apply their technical expertise to ask important new questions and to create tools of broader public benefit.

We found that promoting collaborations of this kind is difficult for several reasons. First, fields have different professional expectations. Computer scientists typically publish a lot of incremental papers as part of conference proceedings. Social scientists typically publish far fewer fully developed articles in academic journals. Finding professionally compatible projects can be difficult. 

Second, whereas computer scientists are very adaptable (they are always looking for places to use their 'hammers'), social scientists are less eager to take up new projects (because their field values deep domain expertise). This was especially apparent with our initial data challenge examining the 2007-08 financial crisis. The computer science challenge was very successful. The political science and journalism challenges received few submissions.

There were a few terrific collaborations, but not nearly as many as we had hoped for. These lessons led us to revise the goals of the RCN from promoting collaborations to encouraging scholars to take advantage of big government data sources. We did this by 1) focusing on junior scholars; 2) curating and sharing data; 3) providing examples of applications (see legex.org) and innovative methods; leading text as data training sessions at established academic conferences; and inviting scholars to present and receive intensive feedback on their research at two multi-day workshops.

When we first proposed this RCN, very few political scientists used computational methods and only a handful of departments taught them. It is fair to say that both are now mainstreamed. About one-third of the presentations at the well regarded Society for Political Methodology workshop this summer used text as data methods. A significant number of the presenters had participated in earlier PI-Net workshops.
